title: Brain Abscess
scope: ** Diagnosis, antimicrobial treatment, surgical management, and follow-up of brain abscess in adults. Covers empiric antibiotic selection based on suspected source, indications for surgical drainage (stereotactic aspiration vs. craniotomy with excision), management of associated complications (seizures, elevated ICP, cerebral edema), prolonged IV antibiotic course monitoring, serial imaging for resolution, and source control. Includes special populations (immunocompromised: Toxoplasma, Nocardia, fungi). Excludes epidural abscess (separate template), subdural empyema, and pediatric brain abscess.

Essential/Core Labs.target: Organism identification and sensitivities; Streptococci most common overall

Essential/Core Labs.target: WBC elevated in 40-60%; normal WBC does NOT exclude brain abscess; neutrophilia

Essential/Core Labs.target: Elevated; declining trend indicates treatment response

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate. First-line in ED for any patient presenting with headache + fever + focal deficits
Essential/First-line.target: **Ring-enhancing lesion** with central hypodensity (necrosis) and surrounding vasogenic edema; thin smooth enhancing wall; may show mass effect, midline shift, hydrocephalus
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Contrast allergy (pre-medicate or use MRI); renal impairment (hydrate)

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24h if CT suspicious; STAT if available. **Gold standard imaging** for brain abscess
Essential/First-line.target: **DWI restriction** (bright on DWI, dark on ADC) = abscess (distinguishes from necrotic tumor); ring enhancement; T2/FLAIR hyperintensity of surrounding edema; thin smooth wall; multiloculated collections

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate if concern for herniation before contrast; follow-up imaging to assess mass effect
Essential/First-line.target: Mass effect, midline shift, hydrocephalus, hemorrhage
Lung abscess, pneumonia (hematogenous source); AVM (hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia); endocarditis-related septic emboli

Extended.target: Amino acid peaks (valine, leucine, isoleucine), succinate, acetate, lactate = abscess; choline elevation = tumor; helps differentiate when DWI equivocal
Lung abscess, pulmonary AVM, endocarditis, abdominal abscess, dental pathology source

Extended.timing: If mycotic aneurysm suspected (endocarditis-related); vascular malformation

Rare/Specialized.timing: Diagnostic and therapeutic; within 24-48h for accessible lesions
Rare/Specialized.target: Purulent material; organism identification on culture; decompression of abscess

Rare/Specialized.timing: If abscess vs. high-grade tumor remains unclear after MRI with DWI and MRS

Acute/Emergent.indication: Empiric broad-spectrum coverage for Streptococci, gram-negatives, H. influenzae; penetrates blood-brain barrier well

dosing.instructions: 2 g IV q12h; duration 6-8 weeks total IV therapy; adjust based on culture results

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Cephalosporin anaphylaxis (use meropenem as alternative); biliary sludge with prolonged use
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: CBC weekly; LFTs biweekly; renal function weekly; biliary symptoms

Acute/Emergent.indication: Empiric anaerobic coverage (Bacteroides, Fusobacterium, Prevotella); excellent CNS penetration; essential for abscess from dental, sinus, or otogenic source

dosing.instructions: 500 mg IV q8h; then transition to 500 mg PO q8h when clinically stable; duration 6-8 weeks total; excellent oral bioavailability allows early PO switch

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Disulfiram-like reaction with alcohol; first-trimester pregnancy; severe hepatic impairment
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Peripheral neuropathy with prolonged use (>4 weeks: reassess); LFTs; metallic taste; seizure threshold

Acute/Emergent.indication: ADD if: post-surgical/post-traumatic abscess, MRSA risk, penetrating trauma, or unknown source; covers MRSA and penicillin-resistant Streptococci

dosing.instructions: 15-20 mg/kg IV q8-12h; target trough 15-20 ug/mL or AUC/MIC 400-600; loading dose 25-30 mg/kg for severe cases

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Renal impairment (dose adjust); red man syndrome (infuse over >=1h)
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Trough levels before 4th dose then q48-72h; renal function daily initially then twice weekly; ototoxicity

Acute/Emergent.indication: Significant mass effect, cerebral edema, impending herniation, or declining neurologic status; NOT routine for all brain abscesses; may reduce antibiotic penetration

dosing.instructions: 10 mg IV q6h (0.15 mg/kg q6h) for 48-72h then rapid taper over 5-7 days; use ONLY for significant edema/mass effect; taper as soon as clinically feasible

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Active untreated infection (relative; benefit of edema reduction may outweigh risk); may impair abscess encapsulation
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Glucose q6h; GI prophylaxis; blood pressure; taper schedule; do NOT use prolonged course

Acute/Emergent.indication: Seizure prophylaxis in brain abscess (seizure incidence 25-50%); recommended for all supratentorial abscesses, especially frontal and temporal locations

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg IV load; then 500-1000 mg IV/PO BID; titrate to 1500 mg BID if needed; max 3000 mg/day; continue for at least 3-6 months after resolution

Acute/Emergent.indication: Elevated ICP management; acute cerebral herniation; bridge to surgical decompression

dosing.instructions: 1-1.5 g/kg IV bolus over 20 min; then 0.25-0.5 g/kg q4-6h PRN for ICP >22; hold if serum osm >320

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute herniation syndrome; more sustained ICP reduction than mannitol

dosing.instructions: 30 mL via central line over 10-20 min; target Na 145-155 mEq/L; may repeat PRN

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Serum Na q4-6h; osmolality; central line access confirmed

Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).indication: Brain abscess >2.5 cm; deep-seated abscess not amenable to open excision; diagnostic aspiration for culture; therapeutic decompression

Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).pretreatment: CT/MRI navigation imaging; coagulation panel (INR <1.5, platelets >100K); type and screen; neurosurgery consultation; anesthesia clearance
Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).monitoring: Post-procedure CT within 24h; neurologic exam q1h x 6h then q2h; wound site; new deficits; fever; signs of hemorrhage

Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).indication: Multiloculated abscess; posterior fossa abscess causing hydrocephalus; fungal abscess (poor antibiotic penetration); traumatic abscess with foreign body; failed aspiration (re-accumulation); abscess wall thicker than 5 mm with mature capsule

dosing.instructions: Complete excision via craniotomy; definitive treatment with lower recurrence rate than aspiration

Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).pretreatment: CT/MRI navigation; coagulation panel; type and crossmatch; neurosurgery and anesthesia; medical optimization

Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).monitoring: Post-operative neurologic exam q1h x 12h then q2h; CT at 24h; wound care; drain output; ICP if EVD placed; seizure monitoring

Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).indication: Intraventricular rupture of abscess (ventriculitis); obstructive hydrocephalus from mass effect; ICP monitoring and CSF drainage

dosing.instructions: Continuous or intermittent CSF drainage; target ICP <22 mmHg; target CPP >60 mmHg

Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).monitoring: ICP continuous; CSF output hourly; CSF Gram stain and culture daily; EVD site care; neurologic exam q1h

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurosurgery consultation for all brain abscesses for surgical planning (aspiration vs. excision vs. medical management decision)
Infectious disease consultation for antimicrobial optimization, targeted therapy selection, and duration guidance
Neurology consultation for seizure management, EEG interpretation, and antiepileptic drug optimization
ENT/Otolaryngology consultation for source control if otogenic or sinogenic origin suspected (mastoiditis, cholesteatoma, sinusitis)
Dental/Oral surgery consultation for source control if odontogenic origin suspected (dental abscess, periodontal disease)
Cardiology consultation for echocardiography and endocarditis evaluation if hematogenous source or S. aureus bacteremia
Pulmonology consultation if pulmonary AVM suspected (hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia) or concurrent lung abscess
Critical care/ICU team for hemodynamic instability, ICP management, respiratory failure, or post-operative monitoring
PICC line/vascular access team for long-term IV access (6-8 week antibiotic course requiring reliable central venous access)
Outpatient parenteral antibiotic therapy (OPAT) service for discharge planning and home IV antibiotic administration
Physical therapy for early mobilization, deconditioning prevention, and focal deficit rehabilitation
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment and cognitive rehabilitation if frontal or parietal lobe involvement
Speech-language pathology for swallow evaluation and language assessment if temporal lobe or dominant hemisphere involvement
Social work for discharge planning, home IV antibiotic coordination, and community resources
Immunology referral for recurrent or atypical brain abscess to evaluate for immunodeficiency syndromes

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately if worsening headache, new confusion, seizure, fever recurrence, new weakness, vision changes, or vomiting (may indicate abscess enlargement, re-accumulation, or ventriculitis)
Complete the full 6-8 week IV antibiotic course without interruption (premature discontinuation risks relapse and treatment failure)
Report any signs of PICC line infection: redness, swelling, drainage at line site, or new fever during home IV therapy
Report numbness, tingling, or pain in hands/feet which may indicate metronidazole-induced peripheral neuropathy requiring medication change
Do NOT consume alcohol during and for 48 hours after metronidazole therapy due to severe disulfiram-like reaction (nausea, vomiting, flushing, tachycardia)
Follow-up MRI scans are essential to confirm abscess resolution (typically at 2, 4, and 8 weeks during treatment, then every 2-3 months until resolved)
Do NOT drive until cleared by neurology due to seizure risk (seizures occur in 25-50% of brain abscess; state laws typically require 3-12 months seizure-free)
Take antiepileptic medications as prescribed; do NOT stop abruptly (risk of breakthrough seizure)
Follow-up with neurosurgery in 2-4 weeks for post-operative evaluation and imaging review
Follow-up with infectious disease in 1-2 weeks after discharge for antibiotic response assessment and lab monitoring
Notify healthcare team immediately if PICC line becomes occluded, dislodged, or if unable to infuse medications (line malfunction delays critical antibiotic doses)
Keep a daily symptom diary including temperature, headache severity, and any new neurologic symptoms to share with medical team at follow-up visits

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Dental evaluation and treatment of all dental pathology to prevent odontogenic brain abscess recurrence (dental source accounts for 25-30% of cases)
Smoking cessation to reduce sinusitis and upper respiratory infection risk which predispose to CNS infection
Alcohol cessation during antibiotic therapy (metronidazole interaction) and to support immune function
IV drug use cessation counseling and harm reduction (IVDU is major risk factor for hematogenous brain abscess especially right-to-left shunt)
Glycemic control optimization (HbA1c target <7%) to reduce infection risk and improve immune response
Seizure safety precautions: avoid heights, swimming alone, unsupervised bathing, and operating heavy machinery until seizure-free period established
Adequate nutrition and hydration to support immune function and wound healing during prolonged antibiotic course
Cognitive rehabilitation if residual deficits present; memory strategies and organizational tools for frontal/temporal lobe involvement
Screen for hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT) if pulmonary AVM identified as source (autosomal dominant; genetic testing and family screening)
Regular dental hygiene and preventive care to reduce odontogenic infection risk (professional cleaning every 6 months; treat cavities promptly)
Avoid immunosuppressive medications unless medically necessary; discuss risks with prescribing physician if immunosuppression required
Gradual return to work and daily activities with accommodations as needed; fatigue is common during prolonged antibiotic treatment
Mental health support for depression and anxiety which are common during prolonged treatment and recovery from brain abscess

differential.features: Irregular thick ring enhancement; no DWI restriction centrally (tumor necrosis shows facilitated diffusion); older age; no fever; progressive over weeks
differential.tests: MRI DWI/ADC (key differentiator: tumor = no restriction; abscess = restricted diffusion); MR spectroscopy (choline peak in tumor); biopsy if uncertain

differential.features: Multiple lesions at gray-white junction; known primary malignancy; ring-enhancing; no DWI restriction; no fever
differential.tests: MRI DWI (no restriction); CT chest/abdomen/pelvis for primary; biopsy

differential.features: HIV/AIDS with CD4 <100; multiple ring-enhancing lesions in basal ganglia; positive Toxoplasma IgG; responds to empiric therapy
differential.tests: Toxoplasma IgG (>95% positive); CD4 count; empiric treatment trial (clinical and radiographic improvement in 2 weeks); biopsy if no response

differential.features: Immunocompromised or immunocompetent; periventricular enhancing mass; homogeneous enhancement (vs. ring); restricted DWI
differential.tests: MRI (homogeneous enhancement pattern); CSF cytology; EBV PCR in CSF (HIV-related); stereotactic biopsy (definitive); avoid steroids before biopsy

differential.features: Extra-axial collection; post-sinusitis/otitis; crescent-shaped enhancement; rapid clinical deterioration; seizures common
differential.tests: MRI with contrast (extra-axial crescentic collection with DWI restriction); CT with contrast

differential.features: Young patient; large demyelinating lesion with incomplete ring enhancement (open ring sign); less mass effect for size; white matter location
differential.tests: MRI (open ring enhancement; leading edge enhancement); CSF oligoclonal bands; MS-specific antibodies; biopsy if uncertain

differential.features: Acute onset; vascular territory distribution; no fever initially; peripheral enhancement 1-2 weeks post-stroke can mimic abscess
differential.tests: Clinical history; MRI DWI pattern (vascular territory); CTA/MRA; timing of enhancement

differential.features: History of prior cranial radiation; ring-enhancing lesion in radiation field; months to years post-treatment
differential.tests: MR spectroscopy (lipid/lactate without choline); PET-CT (hypometabolic vs. hypermetabolic in tumor); perfusion MRI (low rCBV); biopsy

differential.features: Endemic area exposure; ring-enhancing lesions with scolex (eccentric dot); seizures; calcified lesions; minimal edema relative to size
differential.tests: MRI (scolex visible as dot within cyst); serum/CSF cysticercosis antibodies; CT (calcifications); travel history

differential.features: Endemic area; immunocompromised; ring-enhancing or solid nodular lesion; conglomerate lesions; basilar meningeal enhancement
differential.tests: AFB culture; TB PCR; QuantiFERON; chest imaging; biopsy with granulomatous inflammation; response to anti-TB therapy

differential.features: Immunocompromised; transplant; neutropenic; angioinvasive pattern with hemorrhage; rapid progression
differential.tests: Galactomannan; beta-D-glucan; tissue biopsy with septate vs. non-septate hyphae; culture

differential.features: History of trauma or anticoagulation; ring enhancement on subacute hematoma can mimic abscess; no DWI restriction; evolving signal characteristics on MRI
differential.tests: MRI signal evolution (T1 bright subacute blood); no DWI restriction; clinical history of trauma/anticoagulation; follow-up imaging

differential.features: Young patient; open ring enhancement (incomplete ring); less mass effect for lesion size; white matter location; may have other MS lesions
differential.tests: MRI (incomplete ring enhancement); CSF oligoclonal bands; prior episodes; brain biopsy if uncertain

evidence.recommendation: Empiric ceftriaxone + metronidazole +/- vancomycin for brain abscess
evidence.source: Brouwer et al. Clin Microbiol Rev 2014 â€” comprehensive review of brain abscess management

evidence.recommendation: MRI with DWI to distinguish abscess from tumor (restricted diffusion = abscess)
evidence.source: [Reddy et al. AJNR 2006](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18632487/) â€” DWI specificity ~95% for abscess vs. necrotic tumor
[Mamelak et al. Neurosurgery 1995](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/7708172/) â€” CT-guided aspiration outcomes and indications

evidence.recommendation: Total duration of IV antibiotics 6-8 weeks
evidence.source: Brouwer et al. Clin Microbiol Rev 2014; [Helweg-Larsen et al. Clin Microbiol Infect 2012](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23193986/)

evidence.recommendation: Seizure prophylaxis for supratentorial brain abscess
evidence.source: Lv et al. World Neurosurg 2019 â€” seizure incidence 25-50% in brain abscess; prophylaxis widely practiced

evidence.recommendation: Dexamethasone only for significant mass effect (not routine)
evidence.source: Brouwer et al. Clin Microbiol Rev 2014 â€” steroids may impair capsule formation and reduce antibiotic penetration; use only when necessary

evidence.recommendation: Surgical excision for posterior fossa abscess
evidence.source: [Muzumdar et al. J Neurosurg 2011](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22069434/) â€” posterior fossa abscesses have higher morbidity due to brainstem compression and hydrocephalus
[IDSA Guidelines â€” Kaplan et al. MMWR 2009](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19357635/) â€” standard treatment for CNS toxoplasmosis in HIV

evidence.recommendation: Voriconazole first-line for Aspergillus brain abscess
evidence.source: [IDSA Aspergillosis Guidelines â€” Patterson et al. CID 2016](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27365388/)

evidence.recommendation: MR spectroscopy to differentiate abscess vs. tumor
evidence.source: [Lai et al. AJNR 2002](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12223380/) â€” amino acid peaks and succinate specific for abscess

evidence.recommendation: Serial imaging to monitor treatment response
evidence.source: Expert consensus; imaging at 1-2 week intervals during treatment; abscess should decrease in size by 2-4 weeks

evidence.recommendation: Source identification and control (dental, otogenic, sinus)
evidence.source: Brouwer et al. Clin Microbiol Rev 2014 â€” source control essential to prevent recurrence; dental source in 25-30%

evidence.recommendation: Metronidazole for anaerobic coverage with excellent CNS penetration
evidence.source: [Ingham et al. J Antimicrob Chemother 1977](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/73952/); virtually 100% oral bioavailability allows early PO switch

evidence.recommendation: Endocarditis screening in brain abscess with S. aureus bacteremia
evidence.source: [AHA Endocarditis Guidelines â€” Baddour et al. Circulation 2015](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26373316/)

evidence.recommendation: LP generally contraindicated in brain abscess due to herniation risk
evidence.source: Expert consensus; mass effect from abscess creates herniation risk with CSF drainage

evidence.recommendation: Craniotomy for multiloculated, posterior fossa, or fungal abscesses
evidence.source: [Menon et al. J Clin Neurosci 2008](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18078755/) â€” excision preferred when aspiration unlikely to be curative

evidence.recommendation: EVD for intraventricular rupture with ventriculitis
evidence.source: Brouwer et al. Clin Microbiol Rev 2014 â€” intraventricular rupture carries 80-100% mortality without intervention

monitoring.frequency: q1h x 24h post-op or post-diagnosis, then q2-4h; OPD: each visit
monitoring.action: If declining: STAT CT; neurosurgery reassessment; ICP management; repeat aspiration if re-accumulation
If persistent fever >2 weeks: repeat imaging; reassess antibiotics; evaluate for new source; consider aspiration failure

monitoring.frequency: Daily x 3 then twice weekly inpatient; weekly outpatient during IV antibiotics
monitoring.action: If new leukocytosis: repeat imaging; blood cultures; reassess antibiotic coverage
If rising: treatment failure; repeat imaging; reassess
If not declining by week 3-4: reassess treatment; repeat imaging

monitoring.frequency: Daily if on vancomycin; twice weekly otherwise; weekly outpatient
monitoring.action: If rising: adjust vancomycin dose; increase hydration; consider alternative agents

monitoring.frequency: Before 4th dose then q48-72h until stable; weekly outpatient

monitoring.action: If elevated >3x ULN: reassess metronidazole; consider dose reduction or discontinuation

monitoring.frequency: At 1-2 weeks, 4 weeks, 6-8 weeks during treatment; then q2-3 months until complete resolution
monitoring.action: If enlarging: surgical re-intervention; reassess antibiotic regimen; consider aspiration/excision

monitoring.frequency: q6-12h x 48h then daily; especially if on mannitol or hypertonic saline
monitoring.action: If <130: SIADH evaluation; fluid restriction; if <120: 3% saline

monitoring.frequency: Clinical: continuous in ICU; EEG if altered consciousness; OPD: seizure diary
monitoring.action: If seizures: optimize AED levels; add second agent; continuous EEG monitoring

monitoring.frequency: Daily patient self-check; weekly nursing assessment
monitoring.action: Redness/drainage: blood cultures; line removal if infected; swelling: DVT ultrasound
Tiered ICP management: CSF drainage, osmotherapy, sedation, surgical decompression

disposition.criteria: Clinically improving; afebrile >=48h; neurologically stable; abscess decreasing on serial imaging; oral intake adequate; reliable IV access (PICC) in place; OPAT service arranged; able to self-administer or has caregiver for home IV antibiotics; follow-up with ID and neurosurgery confirmed; seizure-free on AEDs
Stable neurologic exam (GCS >=13); no respiratory compromise; no signs of elevated ICP; abscess <2.5 cm being treated medically; post-aspiration with stable imaging; seizures controlled on medication

GCS <13 or declining; significant mass effect or midline shift; post-craniotomy (first 24h); signs of elevated ICP; herniation syndrome; multiple abscesses with significant edema; refractory seizures or status epilepticus; intraventricular rupture (ventriculitis); hemodynamic instability; need for ICP monitoring (EVD)
Need for neurosurgery not available at current facility; need for stereotactic aspiration capability; need for neuro-ICU expertise; need for continuous EEG not available
Moderate-severe focal deficits (hemiparesis, aphasia, cognitive impairment) after abscess treatment; able to participate in 3h/day therapy
